sub_title: Assistant Professor at Eindhoven University of Technology
summary: I am assistant professor in urbanism, focusing on housing and inclusive urban living. An urban geographer and planner, I study residential practices and their meanings, to gauge the impact of housing markets/policies and neighbourhood configurations on questions of equity and social inclusion, community resilience, and intergenerational relations. I conduct cross-national research, having written about urban and housing phenomena in Detroit, Tokyo, Birmingham (UK), Bucharest, Milan, and Amsterdam. My topics of interest include shared housing; urban commons and participation; young adult housing and precarity; homeownership; aging in place.

treasury_media.title: Will we all be forced to share houses in the future? :: University of the Netherlands
treasury_media.description: I'll be there for you - Friends sharing sounds ideal. But with a worldwide housing crisis, will we all end up sharing housing? Urban Geographer Oana Druta (Eindhoven University of Technology) explains why sharing isn't alwasy living happily together....

treasury_media.title: Does help for homeownership bring families together?
treasury_media.description: Homeownership is both highly desirable and inaccessible for young adults across Europe and much of the world. The financial crisis exposed fault lines in access to homeownership between and within generations previously masked by easy access to mortgages and a booming market. Parental or family support are now often a prerequisite for accessing homeownership.

treasury_media.title: Why worry about house prices & homeownership?
treasury_media.description: In the last two decades, both house prices and private home ownership have grown dramatically transforming the role and meaning of 'home'. For many, having most of their financial equity in their home has increased feelings of security, however, the intensified commodification of the home has undermined access to housing, enhanced debt and stimulated new patterns of inequality and financial instability.

projects.title: CoNECT- Collective Networks for Everyday Community Resilience and Ecological Transition
projects.description: CoNECT (Collective Networks for Everyday Community Resilience and Ecological Transition) is a European research project that aims to study and catalyze collective action networks in six EU countries: Sweden, Romania, Norway, Spain, the Netherlands and France. Underlining the importance of community resilience, CoNECT aims to encourage collaboration between citizens, researchers and municipalities in the partner countries, in order to stimulate the organizing capacity of communities by recognizing, mapping, connecting and strengthening everyday practices of collective resilience. The project attends to the needs of cities and neighbourhood communities and aims to increase capacity for local processes of ecological transition grounded in urban liveability, justice, inclusivity and active community engagement in several European contexts: Bucharest, Sibiu, Paris St Denis and Bagneux, Stockholm, Gothenburg, Oslo, Seville, Eindhoven, and Rotterdam. The role of practitioners is emphasised as initiators, mediators or leaders of multistakeholder collaborative networks.

projects.title: HOUWEL: Housing Markets and Welfare State Transformations
projects.description:
In February 2012 a new five-year research project was launched in the Centre for Urban Studies at the University of Amsterdam, funded through the European Research Council’s Starter’s Grant Scheme. The study is concerned with housing  markets and welfare state transformations, and looks to how family housing practices have interacted with different welfare regimes.
The starting point of this project is the emerging reliance on housing markets and family housing property as an alternative to welfare state provision across advanced societies. While family owned housing has been an implicit part of welfare provision in many societies, it has, in recent years, gained a broader significance along with state restructuring in public spending and housing market transformations. This study aims to advance understanding of how emerging socioeconomic conditions, in which housing markets have assumed a more prominent role, are forging new welfare system pathways and types of welfare state. The total project seeks to achieve this understanding through a comparison of six countries: England, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands and Romania.

projects.title: From Revenue to Reuse: Managing Tax-Reverted Properties in Detroit
projects.description:
Project abstract: 
The Wayne County Treasurer offered more than 10,000 tax-foreclosed Detroit properties at auction in fall 2010 but did not sell enough at high enough prices to recoup taxes and cover costs. The Treasurer's Office can make changes that will increase net revenues from the auctions and will increase positive reuse of properties after sale, in part through changes in practices and in part through obtaining changes in the law. Positive reuse of properties promises to slow the numbers of properties entering tax foreclosure and maintain property values over the long term.
